item.title: F-35 flight tests show radar software problems -Pentagon
item.description: [Reuters] - Radar software being tested for the F-35 stealth fighter jet made by Lockheed Martin Corp is not stable enough, Pentagon officials said in a written statement at a U.S. House Armed Services Committee hearing on Wednesday. The issue caused sensors to restart once every four hours of flying due to the timing of software messages from the sensors to the main F-35 fusion computer and the aim was to improve this to one in every eight to 10 flying hours, the statement said. Michael Gilmore, the Pentagon's chief weapons tester, said the program would not be ready for operational testing until mid-2018, a year later than expected, due to delays in completion of the jet's software and other issues.

item.title: U.S. Showcases Commitment to Maritime Defense and Security Partnerships, Investment in Middle East/North Africa at DIMDEX 2016

item.title: Lockheed F-35's Cybersecurity Flaws Cited by Pentagon Tester
Japan, mulling new fighter jets, opens talks with defence contractors
item.description: [Reuters] - Japan has opened talks with Western defence contractors about building a new generation of fighter jets, sources say, in what would mark an important milestone in Tokyo's strategy to maintain its air superiority over rival China. The discussions with defence companies including Boeing Co and Lockheed Martin Ltd come as Japan readies its ATD-X experimental aircraft for its first test flights within days.

item.title: Pentagon opens probe of comments by former rocket executive
item.description: [Reuters] - The U.S. Defense Department's inspector general's office on Tuesday said it has opened an investigation of comments made by a former United Launch Alliance executive who suggested the Pentagon improperly ...

item.title: U.S. hopes for talks with China about possible THAAD move to S.Korea
item.description: [Reuters] - The United States hopes to talk with China and address its concerns about the possible deployment of the THAAD missile defense system that Washington is discussing with Seoul, a senior State Department official said Tuesday. Rose Gottemoeller, undersecretary of State for Arms Control and International Security, stressed that the United States and South Korea had just begun discussions, and no decision had been made to deploy the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) system.

item.title: Defense Stock Roundup: More than a Billion Dollar Contract for GD & Others; Raytheon Also Scores Big
Here's how much the CEO of Lockheed Martin earned in 2015
Here's how much the CEOs of Lockheed and General Dynamics earned in 2015
Lockheed Martin Takes Flight
Lockheed IT secures big wins as it preps for Leidos sale
item.description: [at American City Business Journals] - Lockheed Martin Corp. (LMT) told me at its 2016 Media Day Tuesday that it continues to be “very focused” on its Information Systems & Global Solutions business despite the fact that by the end of the year it will be sold off to Leidos Holdings Inc. (LDOS) And nowhere else has this seemed more evident than in the government service unit’s Department of Veterans Affairs IT work. Leidos wanted to bring IS&GS on board partly because it felt these health care IT capabilities complemented its already-deep portfolio at the Defense Health Agency. Integral to the VA work is a crucial acquisition Lockheed made in December 2014 of Systems Made Simple.

item.title: Lockheed sharpens its energy-tech efforts
Can Orbital ATK Turn Old Satellites Into New Money?
Jeff Bezos Unveils His Grand Plan to Conquer Space
U.S. Navy missile program uses first 3D printed component
item.description: [Reuters] - A U.S Navy ballistic missile program used its first component made from 3D printing, a process that sharply reduces the manufacturing time, according to the weapons' producer, Lockheed Martin Corp. In a statement on Friday, Lockheed said the missiles were part of successful test flights earlier this week. The printing process allowed the company to design and fabricate the component in half the time it would have taken otherwise, it said.

item.title: Boeing Warns Capacity Constraints Could Kill Air Force Radar Plane
Big Time Savings on Small Part: First 3-D-printed Component Flies on U.S. Navy's Trident II D5 Missile
item.description: [PR Newswire] - SUNNYVALE, Calif., March 18, 2016 /PRNewswire/ -- The U.S. Navy's Fleet Ballistic Missile program flew into the future this week with its first 3-D-printed missile component. By using entirely digital processes, Lockheed Martin engineers designed and fabricated the new component in half the time of traditional methods. The D5 missile, the world's most reliable large ballistic missile, now has achieved a total of 160 successful test flights since design completion in 1989.
